question: Which of the following is a coordination compound (not a double salt)?
tip: Coordination compounds retain identity in solution; double salts dissociate completely into simple ions.

question: In K₄[Fe(CN)₆], what is the coordination number of iron?
The central metal atom/ion in a coordination compound acts as a:
EDTA⁴⁻ is classified as which type of ligand?
tip: EDTA has 2 N + 4 O donor atoms = 6 donor sites.

question: Which of the following is an example of an ambidentate ligand?
tip: Ambidentate = one donor atom at a time, but can choose between two — NO₂⁻ binds via N or O.

question: In the IUPAC name of a complex, anionic ligands are given names ending in:
tip: Anionic ligand → ends in 'o'; complex anion → metal name ends in '-ate'.

question: What is the oxidation state of copper in [Cu(CN)₄]³⁻?
In Werner's theory, primary valency of a metal corresponds to:
tip: Primary = ionisable = satisfied by counter ions = oxidation number. Secondary = non-ionisable = CN.

question: Which of the following pairs are ionisation isomers?
For [Co(NH₃)₆]³⁺, the hybridisation is d²sp³ and all electrons are paired. Which statement correctly explains both observations?
options: \text{NH}_3 \text{ is a weak field ligand; uses outer d-orbitals; becomes paramagnetic}
\text{NH}_3 \text{ is a strong field ligand; uses inner (n-1)d orbitals; becomes diamagnetic}
\text{NH}_3 \text{ is a weak field ligand; uses inner (n-1)d orbitals; becomes diamagnetic}
\text{NH}_3 \text{ is a strong field ligand; uses outer d-orbitals; becomes paramagnetic}
answer: \text{NH}_3 \text{ is a strong field ligand; uses inner (n-1)d orbitals; becomes diamagnetic}
tip: d²sp³ = inner orbital (3d used) → strong field → pairs up electrons → diamagnetic. sp³d² = outer orbital → weak field → unpaired → paramagnetic.

question: The coordination sphere in a complex compound consists of:
options: \text{Central metal ion and ligands enclosed in square brackets}
answer: \text{Central metal ion and ligands enclosed in square brackets}

question: Which complex has a square planar geometry?
In [PtCl₆]²⁻, the coordination number of platinum is:
Which of the following represents a homoleptic complex?
tip: Homoleptic = one kind of ligand only.

question: The IUPAC name of [Cr(NH₃)₃(H₂O)₃]Cl₃ is:
tip: Ligands are named alphabetically: ammine before aqua.

question: Which type of isomerism is shown by [Co(NH₃)₅(NO₂)]Cl₂ and [Co(NH₃)₅(ONO)]Cl₂?
In Crystal Field Theory, for an octahedral complex, the energy of the e_g orbitals relative to the barycentre is:
tip: In octahedral field: eg rises by +3/5 Δo, t₂g falls by −2/5 Δo.

question: Which of the following is a strong field ligand in the spectrochemical series?
tip: Strong field end of spectrochemical series: CO > CN⁻ > en > NH₃. Weak field end: I⁻ > Br⁻ > Cl⁻.

question: The colour of coordination compounds arises due to:
A metal ion with d⁶ configuration forms an octahedral complex with a weak field ligand. The number of unpaired electrons and the hybridisation of the complex are, respectively:
tip: Weak field → high spin → d⁶ fills as t₂g⁴ eg² with 4 unpaired electrons → outer orbital → sp³d².

question: EAN (Effective Atomic Number) of a metal in a complex is given by:
Tetrahedral complexes do not show geometrical isomerism because:
options: \text{All positions are equivalent in a tetrahedron — there is no cis/trans distinction}
answer: \text{All positions are equivalent in a tetrahedron — there is no cis/trans distinction}

question: In an octahedral complex of the type [MA₃X₃], when the three identical ligands occupy positions on the same face of the octahedron, the isomer is called:
tip: fac = face (triangular face); mer = meridian (one ligand on each axis of a plane).

question: Wilkinson's catalyst [Rh(PPh₃)₃Cl] is used for:
tip: Wilkinson's = homogeneous; Ziegler-Natta [TiCl₄ + Al(C₂H₅)₃] = heterogeneous polymerisation.

question: Which formula type of square planar complex gives three geometrical isomers?
The stability constant K of a complex is related to the instability constant K_i by:
Zeise's salt has the formula K[PtCl₃(C₂H₄)]. The ethylene ligand acts as:
options: \text{A σ-only donor ligand via a lone pair}
\text{A π-donor ligand using its π electron density}
answer: \text{A π-donor ligand using its π electron density}
tip: Ethylene has no lone pair — it donates via its π bond. This is what makes it a π-bonded organometallic ligand.

question: In ferrocene, Fe(C₅H₅)₂, the notation η⁵ indicates that:
options: \text{5 carbon atoms of each ring are bonded to iron}
answer: \text{5 carbon atoms of each ring are bonded to iron}

question: In Crystal Field Theory for a tetrahedral complex, which set of d-orbitals has higher energy?
tip: Tetrahedral splitting is inverted vs octahedral: t₂ > e (opposite of octahedral where eg > t₂g).

question: A student compares [CoF₆]³⁻ and [Co(CN)₆]³⁻. Both are octahedral Co(III) complexes, but one is high-spin paramagnetic and the other is low-spin diamagnetic. Which of the following correctly identifies both complexes AND the reason?
options: [\text{CoF}_6]^{3-} \text{ is low spin (F}^- \text{ is strong field); } [\text{Co(CN)}_6]^{3-} \text{ is high spin (CN}^- \text{ is weak field)}

[\text{CoF}_6]^{3-} \text{ is high spin, paramagnetic (F}^-\text{ weak field, }\Delta_o < P\text{); } [\text{Co(CN)}_6]^{3-} \text{ is low spin, diamagnetic (CN}^-\text{ strong field, }\Delta_o > P\text{)}
\text{Both are diamagnetic since Co(III) has d}^6 \text{ configuration}
[\text{Co(CN)}_6]^{3-} \text{ is paramagnetic because CN}^-\text{ causes more electron repulsion}
answer: [\text{CoF}_6]^{3-} \text{ is high spin, paramagnetic (F}^-\text{ weak field, }\Delta_o < P\text{); } [\text{Co(CN)}_6]^{3-} \text{ is low spin, diamagnetic (CN}^-\text{ strong field, }\Delta_o > P\text{)}
